fields.body:
5.13pm BST

European markets close higher with FTSE 100 and Dax at new peaks

A surge in the oil price, a boost from Chinaâ€™s $900bn infrastructure plans and a victory for Angela Merkel in a key German state election combined to push markets higher, despite the worries caused by the global cyber attack. But Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

Itâ€™s been another day of records for the FTSE100 and the German DAX, as they both put in new record highs, however the glacially slow progress above these new highs is a little worrying, which might suggest some investor nervousness at embarking on aggressive buying at such elevated levels.

The sectors receiving a boost included oil and mining, while computer security stocks were also in demand after the cyber attack. Sophos jumped more than 7% while cybersecurity exchange-traded fund ISE rose more than 3%. The final scores in Europe showed:

  • The FTSE 100 finished up 18.98 points or 0.26% at 7454.37, having earlier reached a new all time peak of 7460
  • Germanyâ€™s Dax rose 0.29% to a record close of 12,807.04
  • Franceâ€™s Cac closed up 0.22% at 5417.40
  • Italyâ€™s FTSE MIB added 0.6% to 21,704.46
  • Spainâ€™s Ibex ended up 0.56% at 10,957.8
  • In Athens, the Greek market slipped 0.86% to 782.32

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently up 80 points or 0.39% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite have both hit new intra-day highs.

On that note, itâ€™s time to close for the day. Thanks for all your comments, and weâ€™ll be back tomorrow.

4.09pm BST

News from Saudi Arabia and Russia that they favour extending the current oil production cuts until March 2018 is not a game changer but should help stabilise crude prices, according to Capital Economics. Its chief global economist Andrew Kenningham said:

The first point to make is that this has not radically altered the outlook for oil prices. An extension of up to six months had already been widely anticipated, so this is simply a little longer than expected. That may be why oil prices rose by only about 3% today, whereas they rose by around 15% when the cuts were originally agreed at the end of November 2016. Brent crude remains comfortably within the $45 to $60pb range in which it has been trading since last November.

Further ahead, we think the agreement will help to lift Brent crude prices towards our forecast of $60pb by year-end. Even allowing for compliance slipping a bit and US shale production continuing to exceed expectations, these cuts should be enough to rebalance the oil market and bring oil stocks down.

Todayâ€™s announcement also reinforces our view that oil prices will be far more stable in the coming years than they have been since 2014. Significant price rises would probably lead to weaker compliance by OPEC and Russia, as well as to higher shale production. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia, Russia and the other big producers would probably extend their production cuts again if prices were to fall.

As we have argued before, the current range for oil prices of around $45-60 per barrel is probably a â€œGoldilocksâ€� scenario for the world economy. This is high enough to keep major producers afloat and to justify the recent rebound in investment in the energy sector. However, as it is well below the $100-plus level which appeared to be normal a few years ago, it is also comfortable for consumers. All told, the outlook for oil prices remains consistent with our forecasts for steady global growth and low inflation.

3.34pm BST

The FTSE 100 is still heading for a record closing high, although it is currently off the dayâ€™s best levels, but with a raft of UK economic data due this week, the question is whether the index can maintain its good run. Connor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, sayd:

The index hasnâ€™t quite been able to climb back to the 7460 all-time intraday high it hit soon after the bell; however, it is still lurking around the 7450 mark, keeping it on track to close at a new record peak. Thatâ€™s mainly thanks to its buoyant commodity sector; Brent Crudeâ€™s 2.5% surge â€“ with Putin throwing his backing behind the continuation of an oil-output cap â€“ has obviously lifted the oil stocks, while the miners were pleased with the announcement of a $900 billion infrastructure spend in China.

It is going to be interested to see if the FTSE can hold onto that growth tomorrow. The latest inflation figure is released on Tuesday morning and, with analysts expecting the reading to climb from 2.3% to 2.6% month-on-month, the pound could be in for a bit of a boost. Since Brexit that has tended to mean bad news for the UK index, though it is worth noting that cable has managed to keep its head above $1.29 without troubling the FTSEâ€™s record-breaking rise.

3.15pm BST

More positive news from the US housing market.

The National Association of Homebuildersâ€™ index has climbed to 70 in April, compared to the 68 level reached in March and expected to be repeated last month.

Updated at 3.19pm BST

2.38pm BST

Wall Street opens higher

US markets are also benefiting from the rise in oil prices, with investors shrugging off the worldwide cyber attack which began on Friday.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 62 points or 0.3% higher, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite both opened more than 0.1% better, with the latter at a new record high.

2.17pm BST

Moody's keeps stable outlook on Greek banks

Back with Greece, and credit rating agency Moodyâ€™s has kept its stable outlook on the countryâ€™s banks, citing the improved prospects for profitability.

But it warned that problem loans remained high and were a severe challenge for Greek banks, although they should start declining from around 45% of gross loans at the end of 2016 over the next 12 to 18 months.

Moodyâ€™s added that it expected Greek banks to remain marginally profitable in 20179-2018, although the operating environment would remain challenging. Much depends on the governmentâ€™s ability to get funding from its creditors in a timely manner, said the agency.

Updated at 2.19pm BST

2.01pm BST

Lunchtime round-up: FTSE heads towards new closing high

Time for a recap...

Britainâ€™s stock market is on track for a new record closing high, after hitting its highest ever level in early trading.

Having romped up to 7460 points shortly after 8am, the FTSE 100 has dropped back a little. Itâ€™s currently nine points higher at 7444, above last Fridayâ€™s record close.

The rally is being driven by mining companies, which dominate the leaderboard today.

Investors are anticipating higher demand for commodities as China presses on with its â€œBelt and Roadâ€™ strategy to build new infrastructure and transport links in Asia and beyond.

The oil price continues to climb too, after Russia and Saudi Arabia announced they both supported extending a current agreement to curb crude output.

Brent crude is now up 3% today, at $52.41 per barrel, after Vladimir Putin said this would help to stabilise prices.

Chris Beauchamp of IG says that bullish traders were in the driving seat this morning, but also warns that a correction could be coming....

A new record high for the FTSE 100 this morning was driven in no small part by oil firms, which have been boosted by further talk among oil ministers that more production cuts will be necessary. What should worry FTSE bulls is that the index is exhibiting similar characteristics to the S&P 500 â€“ namely that the rally is being powered by smaller and smaller numbers of rising stocks each day; this doesnâ€™t mean a correction is around the corner, but it does raise the prospect of a reckoning that could be ugly.

Itâ€™s worth noting that only 40 members of the FTSE 100 have risen today, while 60 have fallen....

In Europe, optimism has been slightly dented by the news that Greece has been draged back into recession:

And in the last few moments, Emmanuel Macron has named centre-right politician Eduard Philippe as his prime minister. Hereâ€™s some instant reaction from Guardian colleagues....

And other experts:

1.40pm BST

Newsflash from America: The factory sector of New York state has weakened this month, adding to a recent run of disappointing US data.

The Empire State manufacturing index has dropped to minus 1, from 5.2 in April, dashing hopes of a rise to 7.0.

Itâ€™s the first negative reading since last October, and therefore the weakest report since Donald Trump won the US presidential election.

Companies in and around New York reported a drop in new orders, and a decline in employment growth too.

Updated at 1.40pm BST

1.08pm BST

The US stock market is tipped to rise slightly when trading begins, in 80 minutes.

1.06pm BST

Holiday firm TUI has bucked todayâ€™s trend, by falling 4% to the bottom of the FTSE 100 leaderboard.

Traders dumped TUI stock after the company reported subdued demand for holidays to Turkey and North Africa. Instead, tourists are plumping for Spain and Canaries, Greece, Cyprus, Cape Verde and Caribbean, apparently.

TUI insisted that summer trading is â€œin line with our expectationsâ€�, with UK demand holding up despite the Brexit vote.

But while revenues rose 4% in the last quarter, to nearly â‚¬3.1bn, pretax losses (on an EBITA basis) rose to â‚¬182.4m, from â‚¬138.1m a year ago.

TUI also warned that the fall in the pound is driving up its costs, even though it hedged itself against the worst of the damage:

Sterling remaining at rates significantly lower than those seen prior to last yearâ€™s UK Brexit referendum.

In line with TUIâ€™s hedging policy, the UK Source Market had already hedged a significant proportion of its foreign currency requirements ahead of the Brexit referendum, however on the unhedged portion this results in higher costs which will impact the UK business in the second half of the year.

12.40pm BST

JP Morganâ€™s army of City workers neednâ€™t pack their bags quite yet. But it does appear that the Wall Street bank is committed to moving jobs to Ireland, thanks to Brexit.

JP Morgan announced this morning it has bought a new office block at Dublinâ€™s Capital Dock development. The site will hold 1,000 workers, which is twice its current workforce in the Irish capital.

The company has previously said it will move jobs out of London, if (as seems likely) the UK loses its â€˜passporting rightsâ€™ to within the EU.

Hereâ€™s the full story:

Related: JP Morgan appears to make good on Brexit threat with new Dublin office

11.57am BST

Putin backs oil supply curbs

Newsflash: Russian president Vladimir Putin has confirmed that Moscow is keen to extend the current deal to curb oil production by an extra nine months.

Speaking in China, where heâ€™s been learning about the Silk Road plan, Putin told reporter that a longer production freeze, to March 2018, would ensure stable prices.

Putin said:

â€œI have met with the heads of the companies ... and we support the proposal.

In a wide-ranging discussion, Putin also denied that Russia was behind the WannnaCry cybercrime attack, called for a return to dialogue with North Korea, and insisted that Russia was right to miss the Eurovision Song Contest. Ukraine, he claimed, wasnâ€™t up to the job of hosting it.....

11.32am BST

Via Fidelity, hereâ€™s a chart showing how Britainâ€™s stock market has performed under every prime minister since Ted Heath:

Itâ€™s no surprise that Margaret Thatcher delivered the biggest gains. Her sheer longevity (11 years) is one obvious factor. Stocks also rallied after the Big Bang of 1986 which revolutionised the City and shook up share trading.

You might expect Tony Blair to be closer to Thatcher, given he governed for over a decade. However, the market fell sharply in 2000 when the dot-com bubble burst, and took years to recover those losses.

Jim Callaghan gave investors the best annualised returns, at over 23% per year from 1976-1979. But that was also a time of rollicking inflation....

Gordon Brownâ€™s tenure, from 2007-2010, was the worst time to own shares. But thatâ€™s due to the financial crisis which brought down Northern Rock and HBOS, and forced Royal Bank of Scotland into a taxpayer rescue too. No wonder investors suffered.

But we shouldnâ€™t blithely assume that the Tories have some magic touch for the stock market, as Tom Stevenson, investment director for personal investing at Fidelity International, explains:

â€œWhile on the face of it the Conservatives appear to have delivered more impressive stock market returns than Labour in recent years, the economic and market environment has a far more important bearing on the performance of the stock market than who the current occupant of Number 10 is.

â€œFor example, while UK stocks rose by over 500 per cent under Margaret Thatcher (which some have credited to her decision to deregulate the financial markets), stocks across the globe enjoyed similar returns. Similarly, while the markets produced a negative return under Gordon Brown, this was a reflection of the financial crisis rather than Labour party policy.

Updated at 12.17pm BST

10.55am BST

The oil price is continuing to climb, helping to keep the FTSE 100 at record highs.

The prospect of Opec extending its production curbs, combined with optimism over Chinaâ€™s Silk Road plans, have pushed Brent crude up by 2.5% to $52.10 per barrel.

Thatâ€™s good news for BP, whose shares are now up 1.3%.

But itâ€™s potentially bad news for companies and individuals, as it implies that petrol prices on the forecourt will go up. This would intensify the looming wage squeeze in the UK, with inflation already expected to rise faster than earnings this year...

Updated at 10.57am BST

10.28am BST

Greece back in recession as GDP shrinks again

Bad news from Greece... the countryâ€™s economy has suffered another contraction.

Greek GDP shrank by 0.1% in the first three months of this year, following a 1.2% plunge in October-December. That puts Greece back into recession, in a reminder of its fragile economic state after years of austerity and political upheaval.

Later this week, MPs will vote on further spending cuts and tax reforms in return for another tranche of loans.

Updated at 10.56am BST

10.02am BST

Chinese president Xiâ€™s ambitious infrastructure plans are driving shares higher around the globe, says Kathleen Brooks, research director at City Index.

As mentioned earlier, China has been proudly outlining its plans for new land and sea connections with the rest of the world. It aims to spend hundreds of billions of dollars improving ports, roads and rail links in Europe and Africa, to spruce up old trade routes and create new ones.

Brooks says:

The big news over the weekend was a Chinese government summit that announced the new â€œSilk Roadâ€� project, which aims to forge peace, inclusiveness and free trade across the world. China has pledged $124bn in infrastructure spending to bring this into action, and markets are cheering Chinese largesse, with Brent crude rising $1 on the back of this news at the start of the week.

Chinaâ€™s spending pledge has underpinned risk sentiment more generally this morning, with European equities opening higher and US futures pointing to a stronger open on Wall Street.

More details here:

Related: The $900bn question: What is the Belt and Road initiative?

9.37am BST

The FTSE 100 is being boosted by Saudi Arabia and Russiaâ€™s commitment to extending their current deal on oil output curbs, says Connor Campbell of SpreadEx:

The FTSE is (oil) barrelling towards a fresh all-time high this Monday, ignoring both the â€˜WannaCryâ€™ ransomware attack of last Friday, and a selection of weak Chinese data that saw industrial production drop from 7.6% to 6.5% month-on-month.

Rising 25 points to lurk just above 7450, the UK index is already at a new peak â€“ now it just needs to stay there. The main thrust of the FTSEâ€™s growth is coming from the commodity sector, itself led by Brent Crudeâ€™s recovery. The black stuff surged 2% after the bell â€“ and now sits just under $52 per barrel â€“ having been lifted by reports that both Saudi Arabia and Russia are willing to support an extension of the current output-capping agreement.

9.27am BST

Traders have been rushing to buy shares in cybersecurity companies following the WannaCry ransomware outbreak that struck Britainâ€™s NHS on Friday, and companies and users across the globe.

Shares in Sophos, which sells antivirus, encryption and network security products, have jumped 7% to an all-time high.

Other security firms are also in demand, as Reuters reports:

Cybersecurity stocks and tracker products rose at the European open on Monday after a global â€œransomwareâ€� attack disrupted car factories, hospitals, shops and schools around the world.

A London-listed cybersecurity exchange-traded fund ISE whose holdings include software provider Cisco Systems and cybersecurity firms Fireeye and Symantec rose 0.9 percent at the open.

Our liveblog is tracking the latest developments:

Related: Ransomware attacks: 29,000 infections in China as working week begins - live

Updated at 9.34am BST

9.17am BST

Update: The FTSE 100 has nudged a new all-time intraday high of 7460 points.

That puts the index of top UK -listed companies firmly on track for a new closing high at 4.30pm as well.

Smaller companies are also in demand this morning; The FTSE small cap index has also hit an all-time high this morning.

9.06am BST

Anyone who bought British shares the day after the EU referendum is sitting on a very large profit.

Todayâ€™s rally means the FTSE 100 has now gained 20% since the close of play on June 24th, when closed at 6138 points.

Anyone who had the nerve to buy shares then, after a day of wild losses, has done pretty well.

This chart from the FT shows how the Footsie rapidly shook off its initial panic over the Brexit vote, and has risen steadily since.

However... the FTSE 100â€™s rise is partly due to the slump in sterling after the referendum. This has pumped up the value of money earned abroad by multinationals listed in London, and also made UK companies more attractive to foreign predators.

Updated at 9.09am BST

8.51am BST

Anything Britain can do....

Germanyâ€™s stock market is also on a tear this morning, hitting its own all-time high.

The DAX index of top German companies has gained almost 0.5% this morning, extending its recent rally.

German shares have been in demand in recent weeks, as fears of a populist surge in Europe have faded. The amount of money flowing into European equities hit a record high last week, on relief that Emmanuel Macron had won the French presidency.

8.32am BST

Chinaâ€™s ambitious economic plans appear to be driving the London stock market to todayâ€™s record high.

Over the weekend, Chinese president Xi Jinping launched a summit to promote the â€œâ€˜Belt and Roadâ€™ -- a $900bn infrastructure mega-project.

Related: China's Xi lays out $900bn Silk Road vision amid claims of empire-building

Xiâ€™s vision is a global construction spree covering 65 countries, from Asia to the Americas via Africa and Europe. And that is likely to drive up consumption of iron ore, copper, nickel -- which is why mining stocks are in demand this morning.

Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets says:

Metals prices are advancing, helped by optimism about Chinaâ€™s â€œone Belt, one Roadâ€� program.

8.20am BST

FTSE 100 hits new alltime high

Boom! The FTSE 100 has hit a new all-time record high at the start of trading in London.

Britainâ€™s blue-chip index has gained 23 points to 7458, as energy producers and natural resource stocks rally.

The rally pushes the FTSE 100 over its previous all-time intraday high of 7447, which it hit on the 17th March this year.

Mining giants like Glencore, BHP Billiton, and Antofagasta are all dominating the risers.

Royal Dutch Shell is also in demand, following the rise in the oil price.

Reaction to follow!

Updated at 8.22am BST

8.04am BST

This chart from Bloomberg shows how the oil price jumped this morning, following the Saudi-Russia announcement:

7.54am BST

Oil jumps as Saudi and Russia back supply curbs

The oil price has jumped this morning, after Saudi Arabia and Russia signalled their support for a new deal to cut production levels.

Brent crude - oil sourced from the North Sea - has jumped by 1.5% to $51.62 per barrel. US crude oil is also gaining.

The move came after Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih and Russian energy minister Alexander Novak announced that they believe a current deal to cut crude supplies should be extended until the end of March 2018.

In a statement, they said:

â€œWeâ€™ve come to conclusion that the agreement needs to be extended.

â€œThe two ministers agreed to do whatever it takes to achieve the desired goal of stabilizing the market and reducing commercial oil inventories to their 5-year average level.â€�

This raises the chances that Opecâ€™s current supply cut deal, which runs out in June, should be extended.

7.44am BST

The agenda: Will FTSE 100 hit a new record high today?

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

After hitting a record closing high on Friday, Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 may hit a new all-time peak when trading begins today.

Markets in Asia have already rallied, as traders shake off the shock of the WannaCry malware attack and a smaller-than-expected rise in US retail sales on Friday.

MSCIâ€™s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan has hit its highest level since June 2015, up 0.3%. Emerging markets have also posted gains.

Reuters reports that:

Resilient Asian stocks edged up to a two-year high on Monday, shaking off threats from by a ransomware attack that locked some 200,000 computers in more than 150 countries at the weekend, a missile test by North Korea, and weak U.S. data.

European financial markets are expected to open higher, helped by optimism over Europeâ€™s economy.

Speculation that oil producers might extend their supply curbs could also push the market higher. So the FTSE 100, which close at 7435 on Friday night, could make a run at the all-time intraday high of 7447 set in March.

The news that Angela Merkel has won a key state election overnight could also please investors.

Merkelâ€™s CDU party beat the Social Democrats in North Rhine-Westphalia by a comfortable margin, suggesting sheâ€™s on track to win another term as German chancellor this autumn.

CMC Markets analyst Michael Hewson says:

The German Chancellor who only decided to run again for a historic fourth term quite late on in the German elections later this year will be feeling quite happy having seen off her rivals at the SPD, and the challenge of their new leader Martin Schulz in state elections at the weekend, in North Rhine-Westphalia.

Thereâ€™s not much in the economic diary, apart from Greek GDP for the first quarter of 2017 at 10am BST.

In the City, holiday firm TUI is reporting its half-year results.

Weâ€™ll be tracking all the news through the day...

Updated at 8.05am BST
fields.bodyText: A surge in the oil price, a boost from Chinaâ€™s $900bn infrastructure plans and a victory for Angela Merkel in a key German state election combined to push markets higher, despite the worries caused by the global cyber attack. But Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said: Itâ€™s been another day of records for the FTSE100 and the German DAX, as they both put in new record highs, however the glacially slow progress above these new highs is a little worrying, which might suggest some investor nervousness at embarking on aggressive buying at such elevated levels. The sectors receiving a boost included oil and mining, while computer security stocks were also in demand after the cyber attack. Sophos jumped more than 7% while cybersecurity exchange-traded fund ISE rose more than 3%. The final scores in Europe showed: The FTSE 100 finished up 18.98 points or 0.26% at 7454.37, having earlier reached a new all time peak of 7460 Germanyâ€™s Dax rose 0.29% to a record close of 12,807.04 Franceâ€™s Cac closed up 0.22% at 5417.40 Italyâ€™s FTSE MIB added 0.6% to 21,704.46 Spainâ€™s Ibex ended up 0.56% at 10,957.8 In Athens, the Greek market slipped 0.86% to 782.32 On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently up 80 points or 0.39% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite have both hit new intra-day highs. On that note, itâ€™s time to close for the day. Thanks for all your comments, and weâ€™ll be back tomorrow. News from Saudi Arabia and Russia that they favour extending the current oil production cuts until March 2018 is not a game changer but should help stabilise crude prices, according to Capital Economics. Its chief global economist Andrew Kenningham said: The first point to make is that this has not radically altered the outlook for oil prices. An extension of up to six months had already been widely anticipated, so this is simply a little longer than expected. That may be why oil prices rose by only about 3% today, whereas they rose by around 15% when the cuts were originally agreed at the end of November 2016. Brent crude remains comfortably within the $45 to $60pb range in which it has been trading since last November. Further ahead, we think the agreement will help to lift Brent crude prices towards our forecast of $60pb by year-end. Even allowing for compliance slipping a bit and US shale production continuing to exceed expectations, these cuts should be enough to rebalance the oil market and bring oil stocks down. Todayâ€™s announcement also reinforces our view that oil prices will be far more stable in the coming years than they have been since 2014. Significant price rises would probably lead to weaker compliance by OPEC and Russia, as well as to higher shale production. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia, Russia and the other big producers would probably extend their production cuts again if prices were to fall. As we have argued before, the current range for oil prices of around $45-60 per barrel is probably a â€œGoldilocksâ€� scenario for the world economy. This is high enough to keep major producers afloat and to justify the recent rebound in investment in the energy sector. However, as it is well below the $100-plus level which appeared to be normal a few years ago, it is also comfortable for consumers. All told, the outlook for oil prices remains consistent with our forecasts for steady global growth and low inflation. The FTSE 100 is still heading for a record closing high, although it is currently off the dayâ€™s best levels, but with a raft of UK economic data due this week, the question is whether the index can maintain its good run. Connor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, sayd: The index hasnâ€™t quite been able to climb back to the 7460 all-time intraday high it hit soon after the bell; however, it is still lurking around the 7450 mark, keeping it on track to close at a new record peak. Thatâ€™s mainly thanks to its buoyant commodity sector; Brent Crudeâ€™s 2.5% surge â€“ with Putin throwing his backing behind the continuation of an oil-output cap â€“ has obviously lifted the oil stocks, while the miners were pleased with the announcement of a $900 billion infrastructure spend in China. It is going to be interested to see if the FTSE can hold onto that growth tomorrow. The latest inflation figure is released on Tuesday morning and, with analysts expecting the reading to climb from 2.3% to 2.6% month-on-month, the pound could be in for a bit of a boost. Since Brexit that has tended to mean bad news for the UK index, though it is worth noting that cable has managed to keep its head above $1.29 without troubling the FTSEâ€™s record-breaking rise. More positive news from the US housing market. The National Association of Homebuildersâ€™ index has climbed to 70 in April, compared to the 68 level reached in March and expected to be repeated last month. US markets are also benefiting from the rise in oil prices, with investors shrugging off the worldwide cyber attack which began on Friday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 62 points or 0.3% higher, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite both opened more than 0.1% better, with the latter at a new record high. Back with Greece, and credit rating agency Moodyâ€™s has kept its stable outlook on the countryâ€™s banks, citing the improved prospects for profitability. But it warned that problem loans remained high and were a severe challenge for Greek banks, although they should start declining from around 45% of gross loans at the end of 2016 over the next 12 to 18 months. Moodyâ€™s added that it expected Greek banks to remain marginally profitable in 20179-2018, although the operating environment would remain challenging. Much depends on the governmentâ€™s ability to get funding from its creditors in a timely manner, said the agency. Time for a recap... Britainâ€™s stock market is on track for a new record closing high, after hitting its highest ever level in early trading. Having romped up to 7460 points shortly after 8am, the FTSE 100 has dropped back a little. Itâ€™s currently nine points higher at 7444, above last Fridayâ€™s record close. The rally is being driven by mining companies, which dominate the leaderboard today. Investors are anticipating higher demand for commodities as China presses on with its â€œBelt and Roadâ€™ strategy to build new infrastructure and transport links in Asia and beyond. The oil price continues to climb too, after Russia and Saudi Arabia announced they both supported extending a current agreement to curb crude output. Brent crude is now up 3% today, at $52.41 per barrel, after Vladimir Putin said this would help to stabilise prices. Chris Beauchamp of IG says that bullish traders were in the driving seat this morning, but also warns that a correction could be coming.... A new record high for the FTSE 100 this morning was driven in no small part by oil firms, which have been boosted by further talk among oil ministers that more production cuts will be necessary. What should worry FTSE bulls is that the index is exhibiting similar characteristics to the S&P 500 â€“ namely that the rally is being powered by smaller and smaller numbers of rising stocks each day; this doesnâ€™t mean a correction is around the corner, but it does raise the prospect of a reckoning that could be ugly. Itâ€™s worth noting that only 40 members of the FTSE 100 have risen today, while 60 have fallen.... In Europe, optimism has been slightly dented by the news that Greece has been draged back into recession: And in the last few moments, Emmanuel Macron has named centre-right politician Eduard Philippe as his prime minister. Hereâ€™s some instant reaction from Guardian colleagues.... And other experts: Newsflash from America: The factory sector of New York state has weakened this month, adding to a recent run of disappointing US data. The Empire State manufacturing index has dropped to minus 1, from 5.2 in April, dashing hopes of a rise to 7.0. Itâ€™s the first negative reading since last October, and therefore the weakest report since Donald Trump won the US presidential election. Companies in and around New York reported a drop in new orders, and a decline in employment growth too. The US stock market is tipped to rise slightly when trading begins, in 80 minutes. Holiday firm TUI has bucked todayâ€™s trend, by falling 4% to the bottom of the FTSE 100 leaderboard. Traders dumped TUI stock after the company reported subdued demand for holidays to Turkey and North Africa. Instead, tourists are plumping for Spain and Canaries, Greece, Cyprus, Cape Verde and Caribbean, apparently. TUI insisted that summer trading is â€œin line with our expectationsâ€�, with UK demand holding up despite the Brexit vote. But while revenues rose 4% in the last quarter, to nearly â‚¬3.1bn, pretax losses (on an EBITA basis) rose to â‚¬182.4m, from â‚¬138.1m a year ago. TUI also warned that the fall in the pound is driving up its costs, even though it hedged itself against the worst of the damage: Sterling remaining at rates significantly lower than those seen prior to last yearâ€™s UK Brexit referendum. In line with TUIâ€™s hedging policy, the UK Source Market had already hedged a significant proportion of its foreign currency requirements ahead of the Brexit referendum, however on the unhedged portion this results in higher costs which will impact the UK business in the second half of the year. JP Morganâ€™s army of City workers neednâ€™t pack their bags quite yet. But it does appear that the Wall Street bank is committed to moving jobs to Ireland, thanks to Brexit. JP Morgan announced this morning it has bought a new office block at Dublinâ€™s Capital Dock development. The site will hold 1,000 workers, which is twice its current workforce in the Irish capital. The company has previously said it will move jobs out of London, if (as seems likely) the UK loses its â€˜passporting rightsâ€™ to within the EU. Hereâ€™s the full story: Newsflash: Russian president Vladimir Putin has confirmed that Moscow is keen to extend the current deal to curb oil production by an extra nine months. Speaking in China, where heâ€™s been learning about the Silk Road plan, Putin told reporter that a longer production freeze, to March 2018, would ensure stable prices. Putin said: â€œI have met with the heads of the companies ... and we support the proposal. In a wide-ranging discussion, Putin also denied that Russia was behind the WannnaCry cybercrime attack, called for a return to dialogue with North Korea, and insisted that Russia was right to miss the Eurovision Song Contest. Ukraine, he claimed, wasnâ€™t up to the job of hosting it..... Via Fidelity, hereâ€™s a chart showing how Britainâ€™s stock market has performed under every prime minister since Ted Heath: Itâ€™s no surprise that Margaret Thatcher delivered the biggest gains. Her sheer longevity (11 years) is one obvious factor. Stocks also rallied after the Big Bang of 1986 which revolutionised the City and shook up share trading. You might expect Tony Blair to be closer to Thatcher, given he governed for over a decade. However, the market fell sharply in 2000 when the dot-com bubble burst, and took years to recover those losses. Jim Callaghan gave investors the best annualised returns, at over 23% per year from 1976-1979. But that was also a time of rollicking inflation.... Gordon Brownâ€™s tenure, from 2007-2010, was the worst time to own shares. But thatâ€™s due to the financial crisis which brought down Northern Rock and HBOS, and forced Royal Bank of Scotland into a taxpayer rescue too. No wonder investors suffered. But we shouldnâ€™t blithely assume that the Tories have some magic touch for the stock market, as Tom Stevenson, investment director for personal investing at Fidelity International, explains: â€œWhile on the face of it the Conservatives appear to have delivered more impressive stock market returns than Labour in recent years, the economic and market environment has a far more important bearing on the performance of the stock market than who the current occupant of Number 10 is. â€œFor example, while UK stocks rose by over 500 per cent under Margaret Thatcher (which some have credited to her decision to deregulate the financial markets), stocks across the globe enjoyed similar returns. Similarly, while the markets produced a negative return under Gordon Brown, this was a reflection of the financial crisis rather than Labour party policy. The oil price is continuing to climb, helping to keep the FTSE 100 at record highs. The prospect of Opec extending its production curbs, combined with optimism over Chinaâ€™s Silk Road plans, have pushed Brent crude up by 2.5% to $52.10 per barrel. Thatâ€™s good news for BP, whose shares are now up 1.3%. But itâ€™s potentially bad news for companies and individuals, as it implies that petrol prices on the forecourt will go up. This would intensify the looming wage squeeze in the UK, with inflation already expected to rise faster than earnings this year... Bad news from Greece... the countryâ€™s economy has suffered another contraction. Greek GDP shrank by 0.1% in the first three months of this year, following a 1.2% plunge in October-December. That puts Greece back into recession, in a reminder of its fragile economic state after years of austerity and political upheaval. Later this week, MPs will vote on further spending cuts and tax reforms in return for another tranche of loans. Chinese president Xiâ€™s ambitious infrastructure plans are driving shares higher around the globe, says Kathleen Brooks, research director at City Index. As mentioned earlier, China has been proudly outlining its plans for new land and sea connections with the rest of the world. It aims to spend hundreds of billions of dollars improving ports, roads and rail links in Europe and Africa, to spruce up old trade routes and create new ones. Brooks says: The big news over the weekend was a Chinese government summit that announced the new â€œSilk Roadâ€� project, which aims to forge peace, inclusiveness and free trade across the world. China has pledged $124bn in infrastructure spending to bring this into action, and markets are cheering Chinese largesse, with Brent crude rising $1 on the back of this news at the start of the week. Chinaâ€™s spending pledge has underpinned risk sentiment more generally this morning, with European equities opening higher and US futures pointing to a stronger open on Wall Street. More details here: The FTSE 100 is being boosted by Saudi Arabia and Russiaâ€™s commitment to extending their current deal on oil output curbs, says Connor Campbell of SpreadEx: The FTSE is (oil) barrelling towards a fresh all-time high this Monday, ignoring both the â€˜WannaCryâ€™ ransomware attack of last Friday, and a selection of weak Chinese data that saw industrial production drop from 7.6% to 6.5% month-on-month. Rising 25 points to lurk just above 7450, the UK index is already at a new peak â€“ now it just needs to stay there. The main thrust of the FTSEâ€™s growth is coming from the commodity sector, itself led by Brent Crudeâ€™s recovery. The black stuff surged 2% after the bell â€“ and now sits just under $52 per barrel â€“ having been lifted by reports that both Saudi Arabia and Russia are willing to support an extension of the current output-capping agreement. Traders have been rushing to buy shares in cybersecurity companies following the WannaCry ransomware outbreak that struck Britainâ€™s NHS on Friday, and companies and users across the globe. Shares in Sophos, which sells antivirus, encryption and network security products, have jumped 7% to an all-time high. Other security firms are also in demand, as Reuters reports: Cybersecurity stocks and tracker products rose at the European open on Monday after a global â€œransomwareâ€� attack disrupted car factories, hospitals, shops and schools around the world. A London-listed cybersecurity exchange-traded fund ISE whose holdings include software provider Cisco Systems and cybersecurity firms Fireeye and Symantec rose 0.9 percent at the open. Our liveblog is tracking the latest developments: Update: The FTSE 100 has nudged a new all-time intraday high of 7460 points. That puts the index of top UK -listed companies firmly on track for a new closing high at 4.30pm as well. Smaller companies are also in demand this morning; The FTSE small cap index has also hit an all-time high this morning. Anyone who bought British shares the day after the EU referendum is sitting on a very large profit. Todayâ€™s rally means the FTSE 100 has now gained 20% since the close of play on June 24th, when closed at 6138 points. Anyone who had the nerve to buy shares then, after a day of wild losses, has done pretty well. This chart from the FT shows how the Footsie rapidly shook off its initial panic over the Brexit vote, and has risen steadily since. However... the FTSE 100â€™s rise is partly due to the slump in sterling after the referendum. This has pumped up the value of money earned abroad by multinationals listed in London, and also made UK companies more attractive to foreign predators. Germanyâ€™s stock market is also on a tear this morning, hitting its own all-time high. The DAX index of top German companies has gained almost 0.5% this morning, extending its recent rally. German shares have been in demand in recent weeks, as fears of a populist surge in Europe have faded. The amount of money flowing into European equities hit a record high last week, on relief that Emmanuel Macron had won the French presidency. Chinaâ€™s ambitious economic plans appear to be driving the London stock market to todayâ€™s record high. Over the weekend, Chinese president Xi Jinping launched a summit to promote the â€œâ€˜Belt and Roadâ€™ -- a $900bn infrastructure mega-project. Xiâ€™s vision is a global construction spree covering 65 countries, from Asia to the Americas via Africa and Europe. And that is likely to drive up consumption of iron ore, copper, nickel -- which is why mining stocks are in demand this morning. Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets says: Metals prices are advancing, helped by optimism about Chinaâ€™s â€œone Belt, one Roadâ€� program. Boom! The FTSE 100 has hit a new all-time record high at the start of trading in London. Britainâ€™s blue-chip index has gained 23 points to 7458, as energy producers and natural resource stocks rally. The rally pushes the FTSE 100 over its previous all-time intraday high of 7447, which it hit on the 17th March this year. Mining giants like Glencore, BHP Billiton, and Antofagasta are all dominating the risers. Royal Dutch Shell is also in demand, following the rise in the oil price. Reaction to follow! This chart from Bloomberg shows how the oil price jumped this morning, following the Saudi-Russia announcement: The oil price has jumped this morning, after Saudi Arabia and Russia signalled their support for a new deal to cut production levels. Brent crude - oil sourced from the North Sea - has jumped by 1.5% to $51.62 per barrel. US crude oil is also gaining. The move came after Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih and Russian energy minister Alexander Novak announced that they believe a current deal to cut crude supplies should be extended until the end of March 2018. In a statement, they said: â€œWeâ€™ve come to conclusion that the agreement needs to be extended. â€œThe two ministers agreed to do whatever it takes to achieve the desired goal of stabilizing the market and reducing commercial oil inventories to their 5-year average level.â€� This raises the chances that Opecâ€™s current supply cut deal, which runs out in June, should be extended. After hitting a record closing high on Friday, Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 may hit a new all-time peak when trading begins today. Markets in Asia have already rallied, as traders shake off the shock of the WannaCry malware attack and a smaller-than-expected rise in US retail sales on Friday. MSCIâ€™s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan has hit its highest level since June 2015, up 0.3%. Emerging markets have also posted gains. Reuters reports that: Resilient Asian stocks edged up to a two-year high on Monday, shaking off threats from by a ransomware attack that locked some 200,000 computers in more than 150 countries at the weekend, a missile test by North Korea, and weak U.S. data. European financial markets are expected to open higher, helped by optimism over Europeâ€™s economy. Speculation that oil producers might extend their supply curbs could also push the market higher. So the FTSE 100, which close at 7435 on Friday night, could make a run at the all-time intraday high of 7447 set in March. The news that Angela Merkel has won a key state election overnight could also please investors. Merkelâ€™s CDU party beat the Social Democrats in North Rhine-Westphalia by a comfortable margin, suggesting sheâ€™s on track to win another term as German chancellor this autumn. CMC Markets analyst Michael Hewson says: The German Chancellor who only decided to run again for a historic fourth term quite late on in the German elections later this year will be feeling quite happy having seen off her rivals at the SPD, and the challenge of their new leader Martin Schulz in state elections at the weekend, in North Rhine-Westphalia. Thereâ€™s not much in the economic diary, apart from Greek GDP for the first quarter of 2017 at 10am BST. In the City, holiday firm TUI is reporting its half-year results. Weâ€™ll be tracking all the news through the day...

An Australian government agency is considering a multi-million dollar loan to a South African coal mine that would be in direct competition with the Adani Carmichael coal mine.

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (Efic) is considering the loan to develop the Boikarabelo coal project in Limpopo Province, South Africa.

The Boikarabelo mine has approval to extract 32m tonnes a year of raw coal, making it of similar size to some proposals in Australiaâ€™s Galilee Basin.

With Eficâ€™s help, the project could lead to the development of one of the biggest coalfields in the world, the Waterberg Basin, a resource of about 75bn tonnes.

The proponent of the project, the South African-based Resource Generation Limited (Resgen), would use the resource to compete with Australian coal in international markets, particularly in India.

Related: John Hewson says $1bn loan to Adani the 'last thing' Coalition should be doing

It would have the advantage of being much closer to India, saving a week of shipping time compared with Australiaâ€™s coal ports.

A new report, African White Elephant: Should Australian taxpayers finance a South African coal mine?, has questioned the rationale of the Efic loan.

The report, published by the progressive think-tank The Australia Institute and the Jubilee Australia Research Centre, asks why Australian taxpayers should help fund the project.

â€œThe proponent company, Resgen, does not have strong links to Australia,â€� it says.

â€œWhile listed on the Australian stock exchange, it is majority foreign-owned, with a South African CEO and mainly South African board. It appears to have no activities based in Australia. Its â€˜Australian officeâ€™ has a South African phone number.

â€œWhile Resgenâ€™s links to Australia are minor, its South African coal would compete with Australian coal in international markets, particularly in India.â€�

The report says that while Efic can lend money to non-Australian projects so long as there are other benefits for Australian exporters, it wonders what those benefits will be in this case.

Related: Adani may be forced to revamp Carmichael coalmine clean-up plans

It has also questioned Eficâ€™s capacity to assess environmental and social risks, given it has provided finance to some of the worst social and environmental catastrophes in the Asia-Pacific region, including the Ok Tedi Mine, the Porgera mine, and the Bougainville Panguna mine.

â€œSouth Africaâ€™s mining industry has a poor record on accountability, human rights and environmental issues, raising the risk of Efic, an Australian government entity, being linked to these problems,â€� it says.

Rod Campbell, a research director at The Australia Institute, says that while the size of Eficâ€™s potential loan is confidential, he estimates it would be between $50m and $100m, given the $530m financing the project requires.

It would be much larger than Eficâ€™s usual loans - in 2016-17, Efic has provided more than 50 loans worth a total of $150m, with one worth $85m, and the rest worth less than $10m and many less than $1m.

Campbell has questioned the rationale for Eficâ€™s potential loan, given the Australian government is also considering making a $1bn loan to the Adani Carmichael project, to help it sell coal to India.

â€œDeveloping a South African coal mine with Australian taxpayersâ€™ money is madness, no matter what side of Australiaâ€™s coal debate you are on,â€� he said.

â€œAt best the project fails and we lose our money, at worst it leads to increased greenhouse emissions and damages our own coal industry.â€�

In Queensland on Thursday, the prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, said the Adani Carmichael project was â€œvitally importantâ€� for Queenslandâ€™s economy.

â€œLetâ€™s be quite clear about this,â€� he said. â€œIf Australia stopped exporting coal to India, theyâ€™d simply buy it from another market. Theyâ€™d buy it from Indonesia or theyâ€™d buy it from South Africa or Colombia.â€�

Eurozone finance ministers have failed to agree a debt relief plan for Greece, raising the prospect of a summer crisis for the single currency bloc if Athens misses a loan repayment.

A meeting of the eurozoneâ€™s 19 finance ministers broke up late on Monday night, amid a row with the International Monetary Fund about Greeceâ€™s debt burden.

The standoff came just hours after France and Germany pledged to deepen co-operation in the single currency and seize Brexit opportunities for their banking industries.

After more than eight hours of talks in Brussels, Greeceâ€™s creditors â€“ the eurozone members states and the IMF â€“ were unable to bridge their differences on Greeceâ€™s ability to repay its debts in the long run.

â€œWe were very close and we were just unable to manage it tonight,â€� said Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the Dutch finance minister, who chaired the meeting. He said he hoped for a deal at the next eurozone meeting on 15 June.

The eurozone-IMF standoff is the final obstacle to Greece unlocking a tranche of bailout funds that will let it repay â‚¬7.3bn (Â£6.3bn) of loans due to be paid in July.

The EU agreed an â‚¬86bn rescue package for Greece in July 2015, an unprecedented third bailout that stopped the country from crashing out of the eurozone.

Although the headline figure has been approved, Greece needs to carry out scores of detailed reforms before receiving the cash, which is paid in instalments. It secured â‚¬10.3bn last May, but the latest payment has been held up for months.

It appeared the way was clear earlier in May when the Greek government agreed to extra pension cuts and tax increases demanded by creditors. However, a dispute between creditors has become a major stumbling block.

Northern European countries do not want to sign off cheques for Greece unless the IMF agrees to be part of the third bailout. Countries such as Germany and the Netherlands think the IMF will add rigour to the programme and fear the EU institutions will be too soft on Athens.

But the IMF has so far refused to get involved in Greeceâ€™s third bailout because officials think the countryâ€™s debts cannot be managed in the long-run. The Washington-based fund has repeatedly said it is looking for â€œa credible strategy to restore debt sustainabilityâ€�.

At the heart of the dispute is a demand that Greece run a budget surplus equivalent to 3.5% of GDP. The European side thinks Greece can hit this target, but the IMF has long argued that any country with high unemployment, (currently 23% in Greece) would struggle to meet such demanding fiscal targets over decades.

In a sign of a possible concession, Dijsselbloem said there had been â€œfull agreement that the 3.5% primary surplus should remain for five yearsâ€� and eventually fall, although he did not specify a figure.

The IMF continues to insist anything higher than a 1.5% surplus is not credible: its officials are urging the eurozone to be realistic about Greeceâ€™s ability to keep a tight cap on public spending over decades.

Speaking about Greeceâ€™s debt sustainability, Dijsselbloem said there was a gap in expectations between the eurozone and the IMF. He said: â€œWe need to close that [gap] by looking at additional options or adjusting our expectations. Both are possible and both should be done.â€�

Poul Thomsen, the head of the IMFâ€™s European department, said Greece had adopted â€œa much more growth friendly-programmeâ€�, but made clear the other creditors would have to give way on debt relief before the fund got on board.

5.43pm BST

FTSE falters, European markets edge higher

Most traders had their minds on other things than the markets after the horrific events in Manchester. So business was rather subdued throughout the day, with the FTSE 100 managing to stay in positive territory for most of the day, only to slip back after a late bounce in the pound. Meanwhile the FTSE 250 edged to a new closing high, while European markets also ended higher. The final scores showed:

  • The FTSE 100 finished down 11.05 points or 0.15% at 7485.29
  • Germanyâ€™s Dax rose 0.31% to 12,659.15
  • Franceâ€™s Cac closed up 0.47% at 5348.16
  • Italyâ€™s FTSE MIB climbed 0.46% to 21,415.74
  • Spainâ€™s Ibex ended up 1.14% at 10,916.3
  • In Greece, the Athens market fell 0.7% to 783.03 following the overnight failure of the country to win a debt deal with creditors

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently

5.12pm BST

Here are some new figures from the ONS showing a regional breakdown of the UKâ€™s public finances. Larry Elliott writes:

Londonâ€™s thriving economy generates a Â£26.5bn surplus that is recycled by the government to provide financial help to Britainâ€™s less well-off regions, according to an official breakdown of the public finances.

The first attempt by the Office for National Statistics to break down the UKâ€™s budget deficit by region has demonstrated the importance of the capital and highlighted how taxes and public spending are used to narrow the north-south divide.

Experimental data from the ONS showed that only three regions of the UK â€“ London, the south-east and the east of England â€“ ran a budget surplus in the 2015-16 financial year, the latest year for which figures are available.

The full story is here:

Related: London economy subsidises rest of UK, ONS figures show

3.28pm BST

The markets are looking a little lacklustre at the moment. Connor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, said:

The market became more subdued as Tuesday went on, with little to engender any significant movement.

As it was earlier in the day, the afternoonâ€™s main data-focus was on the latest set of PMIs, this time from the US. They ended up cancelling each other out, however; the manufacturing reading unexpectedly dropped from 53.2 to 52.5 month-on-month, but with the services figure jumping to a higher than forecast 54.0. This did little for the Dow Jones, which started the session up 10 or so points, roughly a quarter of what was promised by the futures.

The Eurozone lost some of its lustre after lunch, the DAX and CAC seeing their growth shrink back to 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. Even the previously dominant euro slowed down; the currency now sits flat against the pound â€“ having been up as much as 0.3% â€“ and actually down 0.1% against the dollar.

As for the UK, investorsâ€™ minds were understandably elsewhere. The FTSE nudged 0.1% higher, maintaining a 7500-plus performance, while the pound fared a bit worse, clawing back its losses against the euro but dipping 0.2% against the greenback.

3.18pm BST

US new home sales disappoint

Still with the US, and a poor set of housing figures, albeit after a strong performance in the previous month.

New single family home sales dropped 11.4% in April to a seasonally adjusted rate of 569,000 units, down from a nine and a half year high in March. Analysts had been expecting a much smaller decline of 1.5%.

3.02pm BST

US economy boosted by service sector

And away again from the levity, and some data from the US showing the countryâ€™s economy continues to head in the right direction, helped by the service sector.

Markitâ€™s initial composite purchasing managerâ€™s index climbed from 53.2 in April to 53.9 in May. (A reading above 50 indicates expansion).

Within that, manufacturing fell from 52.8 in April to 52.5 in May, below expectations of a figure of 53.

But the services PMI rose from 53.1 to 54 in May, above forecasts of a flat reading at 53.1. Chris Williamson, chief business economist at IHS Markit said:

Growth of US business activity gained a little momentum for a second successive month in May, but the upturn still looks somewhat underwhelming.

Historical comparisons of the PMI against GDP indicates that the PMI is running at a level broadly consistent with the economy growing at a 0.4% quarterly rate (1.5% annualized). Actual second quarter GDP numbers are likely to be considerably stronger, in part reflecting seasonality in the official data and the weak first quarter.

May saw an encouraging upturn in service sector growth to the fastest so far this year, buoyed by rising domestic demand. Manufacturers, on the other hand, reported the smallest rise in production since last September amid lacklustre export sales.

There were mixed signals for the outlook. Optimism about the year ahead fell slightly, but hiring remained reassuringly solid, thanks to a step- up in service sector recruitment. The survey is indicative of non-farm payroll growth of approximately 160,000.

Average prices charged for goods and services meanwhile showed one of the largest rises in the past two years. The strengthening of business activity growth and rise in prices will add to expectations of the Fed hiking interest rates again in June.

2.49pm BST

It really isnâ€™t a good day for levity, but Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, has fallen for an email prankster.

The governor was deceived by a hoaxer pretending to be Anthony Habgood, chair of the BoEâ€™s court.

In the exchange, â€œHabgoodâ€� starts by tweeting about claims that the Bankâ€™s new Â£10 note has an â€œairbrushedâ€� picture of Jane Austen, before inviting the governor to a drinks party.

Carney appears to be initially taken in â€“ joking about former deputy governor Eddie Georgeâ€™s appetite for drink. But he then slaps â€œHabgoodâ€� down, after the conversation took a sleazy turn with talk of â€œdashing bar ladiesâ€�.

Does it matter? Yes, as it shows that the Bankâ€™s email security isnâ€™t tight enough. Thatâ€™s not terribly forgivable, as Barclays CEO Jes Staley fell to the same hoaxster last week.

Updated at 2.50pm BST

2.36pm BST

Wall Street opens higher

Following in the steps of Europe, US markets have moved higher in early trading, ahead of President Trumpâ€™s first full budget plan.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently up 29 points or 0.14%, while both the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened around 0.2% higher.

1.52pm BST

Over in Athens the government spokesman has challenged the German finance ministerâ€™s view, and suggested Berlin is responsible for the failure to reach a comprehensive deal that would also include debt relief.

From Athens, Helena Smith reports:

Without singling out Germany by name, Dimitris Tzanakopoulos told reporters: â€œSome cannot say â€˜yesâ€™ to reforms...but no to the restructuring of the debt.â€�

â€œThe solution presented yesterday corresponded neither to the targets that had recently been set nor the sacrifices of the Greek people.â€�

Thatâ€™s a reference to the extra creditor-mandated pension cuts and tax hikes the Greek government pushed through parliament last week.

Tzanakopoulos repeated that both the IMF and Berlin remained locked in disagreement over growth projections - regarded as vital to calculating debt relief - and its ability to achieve a high 3.5 % primary budget surplus in the years ahead.

â€œThe main difference between the IMF and the German finance ministry has to do with the growth projections and primary surpluses after 2023.â€�

Updated at 3.25pm BST

12.54pm BST

Germanyâ€™s finance minister, Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble, has just told reporters in Brussels that the IMF â€˜proved to be difficultâ€™ during last nightâ€™s Eurogroup meeting.

Speaking after a meeting with EU finance ministers, SchÃ¤uble insisted that Germany wasnâ€™t blocking a deal to release fresh aid to Greece, and just â€˜sticking to the rulesâ€™.

If everything goes well, he added, a deal could be reached in three weeks (at the next Eurogroup meeting).

Via Reuters.

Updated at 12.54pm BST

12.42pm BST

Sign up to our email

Guardian Business is launching a daily email.

Besides the key news headlines that youâ€™d expect, thereâ€™ll be an at-a-glance agenda of the dayâ€™s main events, insightful opinion pieces and a quality feature to sink your teeth into each day.

To receive the email every morning at 8am, sign up here:

Related: Business Today: sign up for a morning shot of financial news

12.05pm BST

Greek finance minister: All sides must compromise

Greek finance minister Euclid Tsakolotos has tried to put a positive spin on Mondayâ€™s abortive attempt to find a solution to the countryâ€™s seemingly unstoppable debt saga.

In statements released by the finance ministry he said:

â€œIâ€™m quite confident that if all sides are in a mood of compromise, it should not be beyond the wit of man to find that compromise within three weeks. It does mean that all sides will need to compromise a bit.â€�

Tsakalotos said progress had been made on the policy package Greece must adopt and on the fiscal front, with creditors agreeing that Athens should achieve a primary fiscal surplus of 3.5% for four years once the current bailout ends in late 2018.

But the main opposition party, the centre right New Democracy, slammed prime minister Alexis Tsipras and his lelftist-led government saying both were subjecting Greeks to â€œfairytales.â€�

ND spokesman Vasillis Kikillas told Skai channel:

â€œHow many fairytales will Greeks be subjected to? Six Eurogroups have elapsed and Mr Tsipras keeps telling us that the second review and agreement has been concluded.

â€œInstead of getting the loan disbursement and closing the deal, he has got nothing and burdened Greeks with measures worth â‚¬14bn. Neither has the review closed, neither has he got the loan disbursement and of course there is not a word about the debt.â€�

Updated at 3.25pm BST

11.47am BST

Greek stocks hit by bailout deadlock

The Athens stock market has fallen amid disappointment that the eurogroup didnâ€™t unlock Greeceâ€™s next bailout payment last night.

The benchmark ATG index is down 1% at 780 points, with bank shares leading the selloff.

Shares had rallied recently, hitting an 21-month high this month, on hopes that Greece would receive vital bailout loans. So thereâ€™s obvious anxiety that ministers are returning home from Brussels empty handed, with the bailout review still incomplete.

Greek bonds are also suffering, with yields (interest rates) jumping as investors sell the debt, pushing down prices.

Other European stock markets are having a better morning, with gains in France and Germany following todayâ€™s strong PMI reports.

Itâ€™s a rather subdued day in the City, though, with workers preoccupied by the awful attack in Manchester. The pound has dipped a little, to $1.2963, which helped to nudge the FTSE 100 a bit higher.

But I donâ€™t think anyoneâ€™s heart is really in it today.

Marc Ostwald of ADM Investor Services sums up the mood on the trading floors.

Another barbaric terrorist attack UK will cast a very long shadow over the UK general election (for which campaigning has been understandably suspended), the public and financial markets, and renders all else rather moot.

Updated at 11.49am BST

11.07am BST

Britainâ€™s retailers became more anxious about trading conditions this month.

Thatâ€™s according to the CBIâ€™s monthly report on the sector, which found that sentiment fell at the fastest rate since 2012.

10.43am BST

John Hawksworth, PwC chief economist, says todayâ€™s UK public finances paint a mixed picture:

On the positive side, the estimate budget deficit for 2016/17 as a whole was revised down by more than Â£3 billion due to higher tax receipts and lower spending than initially estimated last month. The deficit last year was only around 2.5% of GDP, similar to pre-crisis levels and moving closer to levels that would be sustainable in the long run.

â€œOn the other hand, public borrowing in April 2017 was Â£10.4 billion, around Â£1.2 billion higher than the same month last year. We should not read too much into a preliminary estimate for a single month, but it is consistent with the broader picture painted by the OBR in March when they predicted that the budget deficit could widen again this financial year as some favourable timing effects on both tax and spending in 2016/17 were reversed in 2017/18.

Hawksworth adds:

Whoever forms the next government will still need to make some tough choices on tax and spending in the longer term, as the recent debate on social care shows.â€�

10.30am BST

Todayâ€™s public finance report also shows how Britainâ€™s national debt has swelled since the financial crisis struck, both in cash terms (in blue) and as a share of national output (the red line)

Updated at 10.37am BST

10.12am BST

Sam Tombs of Pantheon Economics has tweeted an interesting chart from todayâ€™s UK public finances.

10.09am BST

PUBLIC FINANCES: Britain borrowed more than expected to balance the nationâ€™s books last month.

Itâ€™s an unimpressive start to Britainâ€™s 2017-18 financial year.

In better news, Britainâ€™s deficit in the previous financial year (2016-2017) has been revised down by Â£3.3bn, to Â£48.7bn.

But this still leaves Britain with a national debt of Â£1.7224 trillion, of 82.6% of GDP.

Updated at 9.58am BST

9.38am BST

Eurozone PMIs: What the experts say

Alex Lydall, head of dealing at Foenix Partners, says this morningâ€™s strong PMI report shows that Europeâ€™s economy continues to impress.

Itâ€™s official: Europeâ€™s economy continues to rattle along at its fastest rate since the debt crisis began.

9.04am BST

The German PMI figures have also impressed economists.

Hereâ€™s INGâ€™s Carsten Brzeski....

...Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets...

...and Pepijn Bergsen of the Economist Intelligence Unit.

Germanyâ€™s private sector is also powering ahead, in another encouraging sign for the eurozone.

Meanwhile, the rate of output growth in the manufacturing sector remained marked but eased from April amid a weaker rise in new business, linked, in part, to a strengthened euro.

8.25am BST
